en.safe_value: No matter how much effort you have put into building a digital barrier around your computer, you could still wake up one morning to find that it, or a copy of the information on it, has been lost, stolen, or damaged by any number of unfortunate accidents or malicious acts. Anything from a power surge to an open window to a spilt cup of coffee might lead to a situation in which all of your data are lost and you are no longer able to use your computer. A careful risk assessment, a consistent effort to maintain a healthy computing environment and a written security policy can help avoid this type of disaster.

und.safe_value: The awareness of the risks, making the risk assessment and using the tools, puts the everyday stress and fear of losing your office or the information at the office, on a lower level. Which at the same time increases personal effectiveness and stabilises the focus that is easily lost in the tricky conditions where most WHRDs are working. So it can have only positive influence, which in my experience I can feel not only because I am aware, but also because I am already implementing some of the tools for protection. — Anonymous Human rights Defender

und.safe_value:
During one year we had several attacks on our office so we started realising the importance of the assessment. We nearly lost everything because of a criminal fire and because of all the water that was used to extinguish the fire. However, luckily for us, we quickly learned from every attack. The placement of the machines on the second floor, not on the third where the roof was burning, not in the waiting area nor visible to the eye, has saved our sensitive machines from the attacks that were normally happening on the first floor.

We also want to believe that putting surveillance cameras, stronger and more secure locks and doors has tired and pressured the attackers so they sticked to breaking the first floor and leaving the second.

Of course we had luck, but strategising helped create the lucky circumstances. — Anonymous Human rights Defender
